title: Design Concept of Cryogenic Plasma Focused Ion Beam (cryo-PFIB) Supported X-ray Microscopy for Multidimensional Biological Systems
content: As x-ray microscopy advances in spatial resolution and the Advanced Photon Source (APS) aims to achieve 10 nm resolution with the new much brighter and coherent light source, the development of new beamline instruments and experimental methods is needed to bridge the gap between microscale to nanoscale structural and elemental analysis of complex biological samples. The study of samples such as soil aggregates and brain tissue has great challenges for microscopy because of their complex structure, multi-scaled details, and cryogenic temperature requirements. Mapping of the brain structures including all cellular objects and their connectivity at various length scales is challenging but vital to advance our understanding of how our brains work and how the anatomy changes in aged or disordered brains. Similarly, the study of microbes in undisturbed soil is essential to improve the predictive power of ecosystem, regional and global models, yet still is a challenge due to the complex multiscale pore structure of the soil, difficulty of preserving sample integrity, and the presence of organic matter and water [1, 2]. Further advancement in these fields depends on new approaches from sample handling to specimen analysis.
